meta.note: What text should display inside the button?
What type of button to display?
The URL to visit when users click the button. Could be a relative link (`/event/signup`) or an external URL (`https://docs.directus.io`).
Horizontal alignment of the buttons.
What type of card to display? Video will show open a video in a modal window, while Link will redirect to a resource.
The URL to visit when users click the button. Could be a relative link (`/event/signup`) or an external URL (`https://docs.directus.io`).

options.text: This block will display the schedule of all the `sessions` for an event. These are grouped by the day.
This block will display a list of speakers for the event. It loops through all the `sessions` for an event and merges a list of all the speakers.

Be very careful when updating page content so that you do not break important copy on the site. To save additional API calls, these global pages are loaded during build time. So any changes to them will required a new build / deploy of the site to take effect.
You can send notifications to Slack whenever a new person registers for an event.

meta.note: Label for the link.
The URL to visit when users click the link. Could be a relative link (`/event/signup`) or an external URL (`https://docs.directus.io`).
Defaults to the index page for the events site. But could be changed if you want to link out to your main site.
URL for the build / deploy hook at your frontend hosting provider that will start a new build.

options.text:
Build hooks are a simple way of manually triggering a re-build for your site.
The build hook URL will depend on your hosting provider.
  • Netlify
  • Vercel
  • Cloudflare

meta.note: Hide this block on the frontend without having to remove it from your landing page. This is a great way to stage content and then publish it quickly for things like announcement or summaries of a particular day of a week long event.
Only Published sessions will be displayed on the event schedule.
When does this individual session start?
What is the name of the session?
When does this individual session end?
A short description of what people will learn from the session. Keep to 1-2 sentences.
What type of session is this? Shows in a badge on the schedule.
Where is this session being held? Usually a link to a live stream, website, Zoom meeting, etc.
Who are the hosts / speakers for this session? If you add a speaker and the event is published, they will be included on the speakers list.
What is the URL to the recording?
The person who registered for the event.
The event that this ticket is for.
This referred_by field controls the referral tracking / giveaway entries functionality.
This is an optional field just to store any additional metadata you may decide to track whenever a ticket is created via the API.
Disqualify this ticket from the giveaway drawing. This can be used in case you discover cheating or some kind of registration fraud.
The nearest active event shows up on the homepage and is used for registrations. But past events can still be accessed by their slug at `/{{slug}}`.
Name of the event.
Short description of the event. Used in SEO meta description.
When does this event start?
When does this event end?
The schedule of individual sessions / talks / workshops / sub-events for a larger event.
The content of the landing page for the event. Blocks can be toggled from visible to hidden – for ease of managing the event and different announcements.
The specific logo for the event. Used in several different places like the header for the event landing page, the hero section, and a few others.
Short one sentence tagline to use on the event badge.
